content.raw:
Ok, in addition to a trivial whitespace fix (7dc8848a5ec7), I've made some additional commits that improve failure behavior:

* e71aa0dc83a1: change `parentName.substr(parentName.find("::"))` so that it checks that the result of `find` is not `std::string::npos`, otherwise `substr` will thow an `out_of_range` exception. Gazebo catches it, but gives an unhelpful error message (`[Err] [Model.cc:1076] Exception occured in the Load function of plugin with name[harness] and filename[libgazebo_ros_harness.so]. This plugin will not run.`). With this check, it now gives more helpful error messages:

~~~
[Err] [Joint.cc:262] EXCEPTION: Couldn't Find Parent Link[fake]

[Err] [HarnessPlugin.cc:84] Unable to load joint[joint1]. Couldn't Find Parent Link[fake]

[Err] [HarnessPlugin.cc:100] No joints specified in the harness plugin.The harness plugin will not run.
~~~

* 0e926c2539f6: prevents the `HarnessPlugin::Update` function from being called if no joints were found; otherwise gazebo crashes
content.html:
Ok, in addition to a trivial whitespace fix (7dc8848a5ec7), I've made some additional commits that improve failure behavior:

  • e71aa0dc83a1: change parentName.substr(parentName.find("::")) so that it checks that the result of find is not std::string::npos, otherwise substr will thow an out_of_range exception. Gazebo catches it, but gives an unhelpful error message ([Err] [Model.cc:1076] Exception occured in the Load function of plugin with name[harness] and filename[libgazebo_ros_harness.so]. This plugin will not run.). With this check, it now gives more helpful error messages:
[Err] [Joint.cc:262] EXCEPTION: Couldn't Find Parent Link[fake]

[Err] [HarnessPlugin.cc:84] Unable to load joint[joint1]. Couldn't Find Parent Link[fake]

[Err] [HarnessPlugin.cc:100] No joints specified in the harness plugin.The harness plugin will not run.
  • 0e926c2539f6: prevents the HarnessPlugin::Update function from being called if no joints were found; otherwise gazebo crashes

content.raw:
I don't understand

I thought the following two lines are logically equivalent:

~~~
-  if (!(this->cmdMax < this->cmdMin))
+  if (this->cmdMax >= this->cmdMin)
~~~
content.html:
I don't understand

I thought the following two lines are logically equivalent:

-  if (!(this->cmdMax < this->cmdMin))
+  if (this->cmdMax >= this->cmdMin)

content.raw: If cppcheck doesn't give a warning, then we can use it.
content.html: If cppcheck doesn't give a warning, then we can use it.

content.raw: The `>=` operator in PID.cc could be problematic since it would do a double equality check.
content.html: The >= operator in PID.cc could be problematic since it would do a double equality check.

content.raw:
added user settings for i-min, i-max, cmd-min and cmd-max

Also changed cmd limit bounds check to skip enforcement only when cmd max limit < min limit.
content.html:
added user settings for i-min, i-max, cmd-min and cmd-max

Also changed cmd limit bounds check to skip enforcement only when cmd max limit < min limit.

content.raw:
we might be able to add a position term, something like [this](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/src/18812da1f459edfb1a06535b33d7df82d9931628/drcsim_model_resources/AtlasSimInterface_3.0.2/include/AtlasSimInterface_3.0.2/AtlasSimInterfaceTypes.h?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#AtlasSimInterfaceTypes.h-123)

with `k_q_p` and `k_qd_p` for position and velocity control?
content.html:
we might be able to add a position term, something like this

with k_q_p and k_qd_p for position and velocity control?

content.raw: yeah, the `I` term might not fix it
content.html: yeah, the I term might not fix it

content.raw:
see my inline comment about PID.Init

I am guessing adding an i-term might help, but will not completely eliminate the drift problem if velocity info are not perfect.
content.html:
see my inline comment about PID.Init

I am guessing adding an i-term might help, but will not completely eliminate the drift problem if velocity info are not perfect.

content.raw:
looks like [PID.Init](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/2943bf3e08f46ced48b46a0ec6726f2967a92942/gazebo/common/PID.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#PID.hh-63) initializes imax and imin to zeros, which will ignore any i-gain set by users.

Also, might be related, PID class has a [weird limit check](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues/1997/pid-max-and-min-command-limits-are-hard), which might be a problem for this use case if we wanted to enforce only positive commands.
content.html:
looks like PID.Init initializes imax and imin to zeros, which will ignore any i-gain set by users.

Also, might be related, PID class has a weird limit check, which might be a problem for this use case if we wanted to enforce only positive commands.

content.raw: fixed in my branch, by calling `.reset()` on the shared pointer.
content.html: fixed in my branch, by calling .reset() on the shared pointer.

Maybe we can add a small integral term to the PID to prevent drift?

content.raw: confirmed detach doesn't remove the prismatic joint. I made harness primatic joint slanted so joint detach will be more apparent.
content.html: confirmed detach doesn't remove the prismatic joint. I made harness primatic joint slanted so joint detach will be more apparent.

content.raw: One more issue, since this is a PID velocity control, the block in the example world drifts down ever so slowly. If I let simulation sit around long enough it will have moved completely downwards. Should we consider switching to position control?
content.html: One more issue, since this is a PID velocity control, the block in the example world drifts down ever so slowly. If I let simulation sit around long enough it will have moved completely downwards. Should we consider switching to position control?

content.raw: [truncate winch force (in my branch harness_plugin_john, feel free to merge if you think this looks ok)](#!/osrf/gazebo/branches/compare/harness_plugin_john%0Dharness_plugin#diff), also extended prismatic joint to extend below ground, visualizing contacts after lowering the block all the way down does not appear to increase the contact forces beyond block weight.
content.html: truncate winch force (in my branch harness_plugin_john, feel free to merge if you think this looks ok), also extended prismatic joint to extend below ground, visualizing contacts after lowering the block all the way down does not appear to increase the contact forces beyond block weight.

content.raw:
actually, after talking it over with @nkoenig we could probably just truncate the output force of the PID controller to be only positive and achieve similar effects.
I am working on a test branch.
content.html: actually, after talking it over with @nkoenig we could probably just truncate the output force of the PID controller to be only positive and achieve similar effects. I am working on a test branch.

content.raw:
One issue might be critical is the "touch down", current plugin calls `Joint::SetForce` during `HarnessPlugin::OnUpdate` at every simulation step to maintain position. This might not be ideal as the robot touches down on the ground, the winch might very likely actually impart force driving the robot downwards. In a real harness, only support forces are applied at the robot torso.

To simulate this, we might have to (sorry @nkoenig) create an intermediate link, so robot is attached to the harness_link and harness_link to the world. Where robot is attached to the harness_link is a prismatic joint with robot sitting at the lower joint limit, or a pseudo-contact joint, in either case the joint only applies support force in the upwards-z direction.

And the harness_link to world joint is PID force controlled like the current implementation.
content.html:
One issue might be critical is the "touch down", current plugin calls Joint::SetForce during HarnessPlugin::OnUpdate at every simulation step to maintain position. This might not be ideal as the robot touches down on the ground, the winch might very likely actually impart force driving the robot downwards. In a real harness, only support forces are applied at the robot torso.

To simulate this, we might have to (sorry @nkoenig) create an intermediate link, so robot is attached to the harness_link and harness_link to the world. Where robot is attached to the harness_link is a prismatic joint with robot sitting at the lower joint limit, or a pseudo-contact joint, in either case the joint only applies support force in the upwards-z direction.

And the harness_link to world joint is PID force controlled like the current implementation.
